It's rare that a developer goes from making an adult game about crime with very adult themes, to making a game about a high school kid who moves to a school for child delinquents and socially challenged kids, but in a lot of ways Bully is like a GTA. For example, Bully is a open world with stuff to collect, bike races to do, arcade games to play and much more to just find and explorer. The mission structure is very similar to GTA, you do a bunch of work for one of the factions, like the Jocks or the Nerds, and the more you do with them, the more reputation you gain, which in turn effects how other people treat you around campus.  The combat is also very similar to GTA, but instead of machine guns and rocket lunches, you are playing with slingshots and stink bombs.  There are also lots of things different about Bully that really makes it feel like you are back in high school. It feels very structured, but that's not a bad thing at all. You have classes two times a day everyday until you pass the highest level of that class. All of the classes have their own perks, for instance, completing one class will show you where all of the collectibles are on the map.  Unlike the protagonists in GTA, Jimmy is 15 and needs his sleep, so if you are out past 2AM, you just pass out on the spot which can make some nigh missions feel a little too time restrictive but adds to the challenge.  I did't have any technical issues with Bully like a lot of people complain about on this port. Overall the game is well made but parts of it seem kind of repetitive, but I still think this is a fantastic game.

Bully: Scholarship Edition feels and plays basically like a trimmed and a lot less violent version of GTA, taking place in a fictional school in New England.  The story is pretty generic: You're new to the school and no one likes you. In order to gain respect you fight your way to the top, blah...  You have to attend classes in order to unlock certain abilities, upgrades and outfits. You also play pranks on your schoolmates in order to gain reputation from the various fractions, do side events to earn some additional stuff and cash or find collectibles scattered all over the city.  The playtime should be something between 15 and 20 hours, depending on how much of the optional stuff you do and how often you fail.  Note that this is a console port with quite a few flaws. The keys are not re-bindable and the only options available are: Resolution, AA, VSync and Shadow quality. The game plays like crap with keyboard & mouse, so I highly recommend to play it with a XBox controller.

Personal Rating: 7/10  Ah Bully. This games getting a sequel in 2016 so hopefully people can get hyped for that after they've stopped ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ themselves about Fallout 4. However let's take a look at the first game.  Bully is an open world game set in a school. You play as Jimmy Hopkins who is arguabley the biggest ♥♥♥♥ on earth at the beginning of the game. Much like Rockstar's other games, you do quests located around the map to advance the story. Very GTA IV like but without any of those silly cars or mass genocides, carried out by helicopters and bowling.  Gameplay wise, it's honestly nothing special to be honest. I can't feel connected to Hopkins because he's a ♥♥♥♥, and I can't feel any sympathy for him or any bullies for that matter. I mean, I'm a nerd, in this game you're basically asking me to steal my own lunch money. But the jokes on him, I make my own lunch and bring it with me *pushes glasses up nose*. But nah, it's not fresh. There's nothing convincing me to do any of these actions apart from to advance the story.   One new thing they added into this game is classes. No, not Call of Duty classes. As in, actual learning classes like Art, English and Science. You might be thinking 'Well what's the point in going to classes? I live the thug life'. Well, these classes can eventually give you upgrades and weapons such as stinkbombs, clothing and even a bike (which I never got, apparently my lack of skills in production and art carried over into this game). Each class revolves around a minigame, like in English for example, you have to make as many possible words out of a jumble of letters, or in Art where you have to avoid pencils and stuff to draw a picture? I don't know what they were thinking but it works I suppose.  Obviously a big part of the game is combat. But it lacks a certain something. Beat 'em ups and Fighting games have never appealed to me, and Bully is basically a beat 'em up with a couple of minigames slapped on the top, with an unrelatable character and numerous little cracks in this game.  However, it's still great. As much as I've complained about this game, it really is a very good game. Graphically wise it might not stand up to today's standards, however they were good for it's time. Some of the characters like the Principal and the Homeless Bloke are well made and I enjoyed the parts of the game they were in. Now obviously I haven't played all of this game, I finished it on my Xbox 360 though so that can sort of give you an idea.  The one big problem with the Steam version is that if you try and change the options, such as the size of the screen, the game will crash. Well, it did in my case, so I'm playing the game in a 4:3 window. The game's options are full of bugs that may crash the game, so be careful.

Ah, Bully. The ignored yet one of the best games by the makers of Grand Theft Auto- Rockstar Games. I first played part of this game on my cousins' Nintendo Wii, which inspired me to buy this game.  The soundtrack is upbeat and great. Fits different situations nicely. I could personally listen to the game's soundtrack for ages and not get tired of it. It has a personal touch compared to other Rockstar games. The storyline is as follows. You are Jimmy Hopkins, the 'bad-boy' at Bullworth Academy, and have been expelled from numberous schools in the past, you are being kept in the boarding school, Bullworth Academy, while your mother and step-dad are going on a year-long honeymoon. As expected, Jimmy hates this new school. What is his plan? To take over it. Not to bully, as the name suggests, but to put the hateful greasers, preps, jocks, nerds and bullies in their places.  The game includes a class system, meaning that he has different classes throughout the school day. He has one in the morning and another in the afternoon with a break for lunch. You can choose to either skip a class or attend it. Skipping the class will lead to prefects chasing you if they find you. Being caught too many times will give you a detention, where you perform chores. Attending the class will lead to a minigame depending on the subject, if you fail you will have to retake the minigame the next time you have the class, if you succeed you will get either outfits or weapons like stinkbombs or slingshots for Jimmy. Once you complete a class 5 times you will pass it and no longer have to attend it. The game itself is one of my favourites. It includes numerous secrets inside it and is overall enjoyable even when you have completed it plenty of times. So, what could it do to improve if there's a future game?: -A bigger boys' dorm, just a detail I would love in the game. The boy's dorm is basically a shack with a few rooms and a place with a tv. The girls' dorm however is basically a big 2 story house with shower rooms and an accessible attic. This idea is unrealistic as there are more boys in the game than girls. -First person. I love first person games, they let you step into the character rather than just play with them. If Bully was first person I would love this game even more. -Smarter AI. In this game, you could punch a little kid multiple times in one day. The next day what does the kid do? He doesn't run away, just says 'Hello!'. This could be really nice if it could work with the different groups in this game, so you can be with the preps but hate the greasers, or be a jock and hate the nerds. I understand that Jimmy is supposed to find these different societies dumb, but it would be a really cool feature.  Do I reccommend this game? Yes, yes and yes. It's an amazing game. It's basically high school GTA. Story could be a bit longer, but the game overall is great and you are missing out if you haven't played this game.

It's a pretty fun concept, but it gets old quickly and the missions feel repetitive after a while. They obviously just reused a lot of assets to finish the game off. It's outdated, but it certainly doesn't stand the test of time. It's just pretty bad, overall.

Imagine you took all the Americana Juvinalia films (the Sandlot, Meatballs, Revenge of the Nerds, Porky's, A Christmas Story, etc), blended them into a fine paste and made a video game from it. That would be what Bully is.  I wish I could recommend it. I wish I could say its better because it's unique and can be a lot of fun, but it does get a bit stale by the middle of the game.  Gameplay wise, the missions are what you would guess. You egg houses, raid panties, french girls and all the stuff you'd expect from something of this genre. You learn different melee moves and you get ranged weapons, both of which are useful in many cases. There is a bit of variety in missions, but some of the missions are the same as in previous chapters, just with a difference of location and enemy. Also, something really, really annoying: Sometimes if you fail a mission you will not get the chance to do it until the next day. I know the game has to punish you for failing, but I would have preferred to just restart the mission.  The story kind of wore on me after a while. I didn't really get attached to any of the characters because they wheeled them around like I was riding a rollercoaster past everyone in the school. I wasn't too thrilled that I had to go through all the factions pretty much doing the same types of missions in order to boost my reputation with them. There was a bit of predictability. I didn't really laugh as much as I would have expected from a comedy game. Though, the ending did get me super psyched and that made up for a lot of confusion during the middle of the game. It feels like you lose the purpose of the game near the middle.  The open world seems small at first glance, but it is designed excellently. There's a lot of nooks and crannies to get lost in. There's a few collectibles, but not the obscene amount that you see in most open world games.  The music is quite unique as well. The soundtrack is usually dominated by bass guitar with xylophone paired with celeste, which gives it a feel all its own. The problem is that some of the tracks aren't looped well and you'll be listening to 10 second clips stop then start again.  Also, in regards to the sound design, some of the dialogue, which is excellent, is drowned out by the sound effects and you'll frequently find yourself straining to listen.  I did run into one bug that caused the game to get stuck in a cutscene. I had to reload from an earlier point and that sucked.  I really want to recommend this game, but it has its share of problems. If you're looking for something different this isn't a terrible choice, but bear in mind that this game has a LOT of annoying issues.
